member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.GaussSeidelMethodD
member.summary: An iterative solver using the Gauss-Seidel method (double-precision).

remarks.para: The method will always converge if the matrix A is strictly or irreducibly diagonally dominant. Strict row diagonal dominance means that for each row, the absolute value of the diagonal term is greater than the sum of absolute values of other terms.
See for an introduction to this method and for an explanation of the convergence criterion.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.IterativeLinearSystemSolverD
member.summary: An iterative method for solving a linear system of equations A * x = b (double-precision).

remarks.para: Iterative methods search for a solution x of the linear system of equations A * x = b. A and b must be given. A is a matrix and b is a vector. Internally the method produces a solution in several iterations. The method stops when the maximum number of iterations is reached or when the new solutions is very similar to the solution of the last iteration (this case happens when the difference is less than a tolerance given by the user).

The result of an iterative method is only an approximation. The accuracy of the result depends on the number of iterations and the initial guess for x. Warm-starting can improve the result. This is done by providing a better initial guess for x: If several similar linear systems are solved, then the solution of one linear system is possible near the solution of the other linear systems. For many applications, like computer games, the same linear system of equations is computed each frame with only minor variations in A and b.

The advantage of an iterative solver is that is can provide an approximate solution very quickly. In tasks like animation, a quick estimate is often better than an exact solution which takes longer to compute.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.IterativeLinearSystemSolverD.NumberOfIterations

member.value: The number of iterations.
member.remarks: This property is not thread-safe.

member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number number of iterations.

member.remarks: In one call of no more than are performed.

member.value: The tolerance value. The default is ..
member.remarks: If the absolute difference of x from the new iteration and the x from the last iteration is less than this tolerance, the refinement of x is stopped.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix22D.TryInvert
member.summary: Inverts the matrix if it is invertible.
member.returns: if the matrix is invertible; otherwise .

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent to , except that no exceptions are thrown. The return value indicates whether the operation was successful.

Due to numerical errors it can happen that some singular matrices are not recognized as singular by this method. This method is optimized for fast matrix inversion and not for safe detection of singular matrices. If you need to detect if a matrix is singular, you can, for example, compute its and see if it is near zero.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix22F.TryInvert
member.summary: Inverts the matrix if it is invertible.
member.returns: if the matrix is invertible; otherwise .

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent to , except that no exceptions are thrown. The return value indicates whether the operation was successful.

Due to numerical errors it can happen that some singular matrices are not recognized as singular by this method. This method is optimized for fast matrix inversion and not for safe detection of singular matrices. If you need to detect if a matrix is singular, you can, for example, compute its and see if it is near zero.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix33D.TryInvert
member.summary: Inverts the matrix if it is invertible.
member.returns: if the matrix is invertible; otherwise .

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent to , except that no exceptions are thrown. The return value indicates whether the operation was successful.

Due to numerical errors it can happen that some singular matrices are not recognized as singular by this method. This method is optimized for fast matrix inversion and not for safe detection of singular matrices. If you need to detect if a matrix is singular, you can, for example, compute its and see if it is near zero.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix33F.TryInvert
member.summary: Inverts the matrix if it is invertible.
member.returns: if the matrix is invertible; otherwise .

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent to , except that no exceptions are thrown. The return value indicates whether the operation was successful.

Due to numerical errors it can happen that some singular matrices are not recognized as singular by this method. This method is optimized for fast matrix inversion and not for safe detection of singular matrices. If you need to detect if a matrix is singular, you can, for example, compute its and see if it is near zero.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44D.op_Explicit(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Matrix)~DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44D
member.summary: Performs an conversion from (XNA Framework) to (DigitalRune Mathematics).

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44D.Decompose(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3D@,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD@,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3D@)

overloads.summary: Decomposes the matrix into the scale, translation, and rotation components.

member.summary: Decomposes the matrix into the scale, translation, and rotation components.
member.param: The scale component of the matrix.
The rotation component of the matrix.
The translation component of the matrix.
member.returns: if the matrix was successfully decomposed; otherwise, .

remarks.para: This method assumes that the matrix is a 3D scale/rotation/translation (SRT) matrix. returns when the matrix is not a valid SRT matrix. This is the case when two or more of the scale values are 0 or the last row of the matrix is something other than (0, 0, 0, 1).
is a faster version of this method that can be used when it is certain that the matrix is a valid SRT matrix.

member.example:
The following example shows how to compose the matrix scale, rotation, and translation components.
Matrix44D srt = Matrix44D.CreateTranslation(translation) * Matrix44D.CreateRotation(rotation) * Matrix44D.CreateScale(scale);

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44D.TryInvert
member.summary: Inverts the matrix if it is invertible.
member.returns: if the matrix is invertible; otherwise .

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent to , except that no exceptions are thrown. The return value indicates whether the operation was successful.

Due to numerical errors it can happen that some singular matrices are not recognized as singular by this method. This method is optimized for fast matrix inversion and not for safe detection of singular matrices. If you need to detect if a matrix is singular, you can, for example, compute its and see if it is near zero.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44D.TransformPosition(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3D)
member.summary: Transforms a position.
member.returns: The transformed position.

remarks.para: By using homogeneous coordinates 4 x 4 matrices can be used to define affine transformations or projective transformations in 3D space. When a 3D vector is given, the vector can have multiple meanings.

Position Vectors: A position vector identifies a point in 3D. Use to transform position vectors. This method interprets the given as a vector (x, y, z, 1) in homogeneous coordinates. The position vector is transformed by multiplication with the 4 x 4 matrix.

Direction Vectors: A direction vector (or displacement vector) defines a direction and length in 3D. Use to transform direction vectors. This method interprets the given as a vector (x, y, z, 0) in homogeneous coordinates. The direction vector is transformed by multiplication with the upper, left 3 x 3 corner of the transformation matrix.

Tangent Vectors: A tangent vector (surface tangent) defines a tangential direction at a point on a surface. They can be treated similar to direction vectors. Use to transform tangent vectors and binormals vectors.

Normal vectors: A normal vector (surface normal) is a vector that is perpendicular to the tangent plane of a given point on a surface. In differential geometry normal vectors are "tangent covectors" or "cotangent vectors". They need to be treated differently than direction vectors or tangent vectors. Use to transform normal vectors. A normal vector is transformed by multiplication with transpose of the inverse of the upper, left 3 x 3 corner of the transformation matrix.
(Note: If the transformation matrix contains only rotations, translations and uniform scalings then can be used to transform normal vectors, which is faster.)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44D.TransformDirection(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3D)
member.summary: Transforms a direction vector (or tangent vector).
member.returns: The transformed direction vector.

member.summary: Creates a right-handed look-at matrix (view matrix). (Only available in the XNA-compatible build.)
member.param: The target at which the viewer is looking.
The direction that is "up" from the viewer's point of view. (Does not need to be normalized.)
member.returns: The right-handed look-at matrix (view matrix).

remarks.para: This method is available only in the XNA-compatible build of the DigitalRune.Mathematics.dll.

A look-at matrix is also known as view matrix. It transforms a position from world space to the view space. In view space x-axis points to the right, the y-axis points up, and the z-axis points towards the viewer.

member.exception: The camera direction ( - ) is probably pointing in the same or opposite direction as . (The two vectors must not be parallel.)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44D.CreateOrthographic(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a right-handed, orthographic projection matrix. (Only available in the XNA compatible build.)
member.param: The width of the view volume.
The height of the view volume.
The minimum z-value of the view volume. (Distance of the near view plane.)
The maximum z-value of the view volume. (Distance of the far view plane.)
member.returns: The right-handed orthographic projection matrix.

remarks.para: This method is available only in the XNA-compatible build of the DigitalRune.Mathematics.dll.
In contrast to all preceding coordinate spaces (model space, world space, view space) the projection space is left-handed! This is necessary because DirectX uses a left-handed clip space.
In the projection space the x and y-coordinates range from 1 to 1, and the z-coordinates range from 0 (near) to 1 (far).

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44F.Decompose(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F@,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF@,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F@)

overloads.summary: Decomposes the matrix into the scale, translation, and rotation components.

member.summary: Decomposes the matrix into the scale, translation, and rotation components.
member.param: The scale component of the matrix.
The rotation component of the matrix.
The translation component of the matrix.
member.returns: if the matrix was successfully decomposed; otherwise, .

remarks.para: This method assumes that the matrix is a 3D scale/rotation/translation (SRT) matrix. returns when the matrix is not a valid SRT matrix. This is the case when two or more of the scale values are 0 or the last row of the matrix is something other than (0, 0, 0, 1).
is a faster version of this method that can be used when it is certain that the matrix is a valid SRT matrix.

member.example:
The following example shows how to compose the matrix scale, rotation, and translation components.
Matrix44F srt = Matrix44F.CreateTranslation(translation) * Matrix44F.CreateRotation(rotation) * Matrix44F.CreateScale(scale);

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44F.TryInvert
member.summary: Inverts the matrix if it is invertible.
member.returns: if the matrix is invertible; otherwise .

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent to , except that no exceptions are thrown. The return value indicates whether the operation was successful.

Due to numerical errors it can happen that some singular matrices are not recognized as singular by this method. This method is optimized for fast matrix inversion and not for safe detection of singular matrices. If you need to detect if a matrix is singular, you can, for example, compute its and see if it is near zero.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44F.TransformPosition(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F)
member.summary: Transforms a position.
member.returns: The transformed position.

remarks.para: By using homogeneous coordinates 4 x 4 matrices can be used to define affine transformations or projective transformations in 3D space. When a 3D vector is given, the vector can have multiple meanings.

Position Vectors: A position vector identifies a point in 3D. Use to transform position vectors. This method interprets the given as a vector (x, y, z, 1) in homogeneous coordinates. The position vector is transformed by multiplication with the 4 x 4 matrix.

Direction Vectors: A direction vector (or displacement vector) defines a direction and length in 3D. Use to transform direction vectors. This method interprets the given as a vector (x, y, z, 0) in homogeneous coordinates. The direction vector is transformed by multiplication with the upper, left 3 x 3 corner of the transformation matrix.

Tangent Vectors: A tangent vector (surface tangent) defines a tangential direction at a point on a surface. They can be treated similar to direction vectors. Use to transform tangent vectors and binormals vectors.

Normal vectors: A normal vector (surface normal) is a vector that is perpendicular to the tangent plane of a given point on a surface. In differential geometry normal vectors are "tangent covectors" or "cotangent vectors". They need to be treated differently than direction vectors or tangent vectors. Use to transform normal vectors. A normal vector is transformed by multiplication with transpose of the inverse of the upper, left 3 x 3 corner of the transformation matrix.
(Note: If the transformation matrix contains only rotations, translations and uniform scalings then can be used to transform normal vectors, which is faster.)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44F.CreateLookAt(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F)
member.summary: Creates a right-handed look-at matrix (view matrix). (Only available in the XNA-compatible build.)
member.param: The target at which the viewer is looking.
The direction that is "up" from the viewer's point of view. (Does not need to be normalized.)
member.returns: The right-handed look-at matrix (view matrix).

remarks.para: This method is available only in the XNA-compatible build of the DigitalRune.Mathematics.dll.

A look-at matrix is also known as view matrix. It transforms a position from world space to the view space. In view space x-axis points to the right, the y-axis points up, and the z-axis points towards the viewer.

member.exception: The camera direction ( - ) is probably pointing in the same or opposite direction as . (The two vectors must not be parallel.)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Matrix44F.CreateOrthographic(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a right-handed, orthographic projection matrix. (Only available in the XNA compatible build.)
member.param: The width of the view volume.
The height of the view volume.
The minimum z-value of the view volume. (Distance of the near view plane.)
The maximum z-value of the view volume. (Distance of the far view plane.)
member.returns: The right-handed orthographic projection matrix.

remarks.para: This method is available only in the XNA-compatible build of the DigitalRune.Mathematics.dll.
In contrast to all preceding coordinate spaces (model space, world space, view space) the projection space is left-handed! This is necessary because DirectX uses a left-handed clip space.
In the projection space the x and y-coordinates range from 1 to 1, and the z-coordinates range from 0 (near) to 1 (far).

member.exception: is greater than or equal to .

remarks.para: This method is available only in the XNA-compatible build of the DigitalRune.Mathematics.dll.
In contrast to all preceding coordinate spaces (model space, world space, view space) the projection space is left-handed! This is necessary because DirectX uses a left-handed clip space.
In the projection space the x and y-coordinates range from 1 to 1, and the z-coordinates range from 0 (near) to 1 (far).

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixD
member.summary: Defines an m x n matrix (double-precision).

remarks.para:
All indices are zero-based. The first index is the row, the second is the column:
[0,0] [0,1] [0,2] ... [1,0] [1,1] [1,2] ... [2,0] [2,1] [2,2] ... ... ... ... ...

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.CholeskyDecompositionD
member.summary: Computes the Cholesky Decomposition of a matrix (double-precision).

remarks.para: The Cholesky Decomposition can be used on a square matrix A that is symmetric and positive definite (SPD).
Positive definite means that: vT * A * v > 0 for all vectors v. (The equivalent interpretation is that A has all positive eigenvalues.)
The matrix is decomposed into a lower triangular matrix L so that A = L * LT
If the matrix is not symmetric and positive definite, L will be a partial decomposition and the flag is set to .

Applications:
Cholesky Decomposition can be used to solve linear equations for matrices that are SPD. This method is about a factor of 2 faster than other methods.
It can be used to determine efficiently if a matrix is SPD.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.CholeskyDecompositionD.IsSymmetricPositiveDefinite
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the original matrix is symmetric and positive definite.
member.value: if the original matrix is symmetric and positive definite; otherwise, .

member.summary: Gets the lower triangular matrix L. (This property returns the internal matrix, not a copy.)
member.value: The lower triangular matrix L.

member.summary: Creates the Cholesky decomposition of the given matrix.

member.param: The matrix B with as many rows as A and any number of columns.
member.returns: X, so that A * X = B.

The matrix A is not symmetric and positive definite.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.EigenvalueDecompositionD
member.summary: Computes the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real square matrix A (double-precision).

remarks.para: If the matrix A is symmetric, then A = V * D * VT where the eigenvalue matrix D is a diagonal matrix and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal.

If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1 x 1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues ( + i*) in 2 x 2 blocks ((, ),(-, )). The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A * V = V * D. The matrix V may be badly conditioned or even singular; so if the inverse of V can be computed depends on the condition number of V. (The condition number can be checked with .)

member.summary: Gets the vector of the imaginary parts of the eigenvalues.
member.value: The vector of the imaginary parts of the eigenvalues.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.LUDecompositionD
member.summary: Computes the LU Decomposition of a matrix (double-precision).

remarks.para: The LU Decomposition computes a unit lower triangular matrix L and an upper triangular matrix U for a matrix A so that A' = L * U where A' is a row-permutation of A.
The LU Decomposition with pivoting always exists, even if the matrix is singular.
Application: LU Decomposition is the preferred way to solve a linear set of equations. This will fail if the matrix A is singular.
Use QR Decomposition for rectangular matrices A with m n.

member.value: The determinant of matrix A.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix U is numerically singular.
member.value: if this the matrix U is numerically singular; otherwise, .

remarks.para: If U is singular A is singular too.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QRDecompositionD
member.summary: Computes the QR Decomposition of a matrix (double-precision).

remarks.para: For an m x n matrix A with m n the QR Decomposition computes an orthogonal matrix Q and a upper triangular matrix R so that A = Q * R.
The QR Decomposition always exists, even if the matrix does not have full rank.
Application: The primary use of QR Decomposition is in computing the least squares solution for non-square sets of linear equations. This will fail if the matrix does not have full rank.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QRDecompositionD.HasNumericallyFullRank
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix R has full rank (numerically).
member.value: if the matrix R has full rank (numerically); otherwise, .
member.remarks: If R has full rank, A has full column rank, i. e. all column vectors are linearly independent.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QRDecompositionD.H
member.summary: Gets the matrix H with the Householder vectors. (This property returns the internal matrix, not a copy.)
member.value: The lower trapezoidal matrix whose columns define the reflections.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QRDecompositionD.Q
member.summary: Gets the orthogonal matrix Q. (This property returns the internal matrix, not a copy.)
member.value: The orthogonal matrix Q.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QRDecompositionD.R
member.summary: Gets the upper triangular matrix R. (This property returns the internal matrix, not a copy.)
member.value: The upper triangular matrix R.

member.summary: Creates the QR decomposition of the given matrix.
member.param: The matrix A. (Can be rectangular. NumberOfRows must be NumberOfColumns.)
member.remarks: The QR decomposition is computed by Householder reflections.
member.exception: The number of rows must be greater than or equal to the number of columns.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD
member.summary: Computes the Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) of a matrix (double-precision).

remarks.para: For an m x n matrix A with m n, the SVD computes the matrices U, S and V so that A = U * S * VT.
U is an m x n orthogonal matrix. S is an n x n diagonal matrix. V is is a n x n orthogonal matrix.
The diagonal elements of S are the singular values. The singular values are positive or zero and ordered so that S[0, 0] S[1, 1] ...
The singular value decomposition always exists.
Applications: The matrix condition number and the effective numerical rank can be computed from this decomposition.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD.ConditionNumber
member.summary: Gets the condition number of A.
member.value: The condition number of A.
member.remarks: The condition number is the ratio of the largest (in magnitude) of the singular values to the smallest singular value. The matrix is singular if the condition number is infinite and the matrix is ill-conditioned if its condition number is too large, i.e. if the reciprocal approaches the machine's floating-point precision (less than 10^-6 for ).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD.S
member.summary: Gets the diagonal matrix S with the singular values. (This property returns the internal matrix, not a copy.)
member.value: The diagonal matrix S with the singular values.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD.U
member.summary: Gets the matrix U with the left singular vectors. (This property returns the internal matrix, not a copy.)
member.value: The matrix U with the left singular vectors.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD.V
member.summary: Gets the matrix V with the right singular vectors. (This property returns the internal matrix, not a copy.)
member.value: The matrix V with the right singular vectors.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD.Norm2
member.summary: Gets the two norm of A.
member.value: The two norm of A.
member.remarks: The two norm is equal to the first (largest) singular value.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD.NumericalRank
member.summary: Gets the effective numerical rank of A.
member.value: The effective numerical rank of A.
member.remarks: Near-zero singular values are considered as zero. The rank is the number of singular values greater than 0.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SingularValueDecompositionD.SingularValues
member.summary: Gets the vector of singular values (the diagonal of S).
member.value: The vector of singular values.

member.summary: Creates the singular value decomposition of the given matrix.
member.param: The matrix A. (Can be rectangular. Number of rows number of columns.)
member.exception: The number of rows must be greater than or equal to the number of columns.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixF.SolveLinearEquations(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixF)
member.summary: Solves the linear set of equations A * X = B.
member.param: The matrix A. (Can be rectangular. Number of rows number of columns.)
The matrix B with the same number of rows as A and any number of columns.
member.returns: The matrix X.
member.remarks: If A is a square matrix, the X contains the solutions. If A is not a square matrix, the least squares solutions is returned.
member.exception: The number of rows does not match.
The number of rows in must be greater than or equal to the number of columns.
The matrix A does not have full rank.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixF.SolveLinearEquations(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.VectorF)
member.summary: Solves the linear set of equations A * x = b.
member.param: The matrix A. (Can be rectangular. Number of rows number of columns.)
The column vector b with as many rows as A.
member.returns: The vector x.
member.remarks: If A is a square matrix, the x contains the solutions. If A is not a square matrix, the least squares solutions is returned.
member.exception: The number of rows does not match.
The number of rows in matrix A must be greater than or equal to the number of columns.
The matrix A does not have full rank.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixOrder

member.remarks:
The enumeration values are explained using following example matrix:
M00 M01 M02 M10 M11 M12

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixOrder.ColumnMajor
member.summary: The matrix is stored in column-major order. (Example: M00, M10, M01, M11, M02, M12)

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.MatrixOrder.RowMajor
member.summary: The matrix is stored in row-major order. (Example: M00, M01, M02, M10, M11, M12)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD
member.summary: Defines a quaternion (double-precision).

remarks.para: A quaternion consists of a scalar component w and a vector component v = (x, y, z). Alternatively it can be represented as a complex number with three imaginary parts w + ix + jy + kz, or as a 4-dimensional vector (w, x, y, z)
Due to common notation, the quaternion components are stored in the order: (w, x, y, z).

para.para: A unit quaternion is a quaternion q where N(q) = 1. (See .) A unit quaternion can be represented by
where u as a 3D vector has a length of 1. By applying Euler's identity for complex numbers the quaternion can be written in exponential notation:

remarks.para: Several methods, such as , require that the quaternion is a unit quaternion.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD.op_Multiply(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD)
member.summary: Multiplies two quaternions.
member.returns: The product of the two quaternions.

remarks.para: If the quaternions are unit quaternions, then each quaternion represents a rotation in 3-dimensional space. The product of two unit quaternions is the concatenation of the two rotations.
q2 q1 is the same as M2 . M1, where M2 and M1 are the equivalent matrices (M1 specifies the same rotation as q1 and M2 specifies the same rotation as q2).
The multiplication is non-commutative. The operation is also known as the Grassman product of quaternions.
The multiplication is defined as:
q1 q2 = (w1 w2 - v1 v2, v1 x v2 + w1 v2 + w2 v1)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD.Multiply(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD)
member.summary: Multiplies two quaternions.
member.returns: The product of the two quaternions.

remarks.para: If the quaternions are unit quaternions, then each quaternion represents a rotation in 3-dimensional space. The product of two unit quaternions is the concatenation of the two rotations.
q1 . q2 is the same as M1 . M2, where M1 and M2 are the equivalent matrices (M1 specifies the same rotation as q1 and M2 specifies the same rotation as q2).
The multiplication is non-commutative. The operation is also known as the Grassman product of quaternions.
The multiplication is defined as:
q1 q2 = (w1 w2 - v1 v2, v1 x v2 + w1 v2 + w2 v1)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD.Exp

overloads.summary: Calculates the exponential.

member.summary: Sets this quaternion to its exponential.

remarks.para: Important: This method requires that the quaternion is a pure quaternion. A pure quaternion is defined by q = (0, u) where u is a unit vector.
The exponential of a quaternion q is defines as:
eq = (cos() + usin())
The result is returned as a quaternion with the form: (cos(), usin())

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD.Ln

overloads.summary: Calculates the natural logarithm.

member.summary: Sets this quaternion to its natural logarithm.

remarks.para: Important: This method requires that the quaternion is a unit quaternion.
The natural logarithm of a quaternion q is defines as:
ln(q) = ln(cos() + usin()) = ln(eu) = u
The result is returned as a quaternion with the form: (0, u)

member.exception: The quaternion is not a unit quaternion.

member.returns: The power of the unit quaternion.

remarks.para: Important: This method requires that the quaternion is a unit quaternion.
The power of quaternion is defined as:
qt = eut = cos(t) + usin(t)

member.summary: Gets an orientation quaternion from Euler angles (3 rotations around 3 axes).
member.param: If set to then the rotation axes are fixed in world space. Otherwise the rotation axes are fixed on the object and rotated with each rotation.
member.remarks: A rotation is created from 3 sequential rotations. Each rotation is defined by an angle and the rotation axis. This method can be used to create a quaternion from Euler angle representations, often named Azimuth/Elevation/Roll, or Heading/Pitch/Roll.
member.returns: The orientation quaternion that describes the same orientation as the given Euler angles.
member.exception: The length of the axis vectors must not be 0.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF
member.summary: Defines a quaternion (single-precision).

remarks.para: A quaternion consists of a scalar component w and a vector component v = (x, y, z). Alternatively it can be represented as a complex number with three imaginary parts w + ix + jy + kz, or as a 4-dimensional vector (w, x, y, z)
Due to common notation, the quaternion components are stored in the order: (w, x, y, z).

para.para: A unit quaternion is a quaternion q where N(q) = 1. (See .) A unit quaternion can be represented by
where u as a 3D vector has a length of 1. By applying Euler's identity for complex numbers the quaternion can be written in exponential notation:

remarks.para: Several methods, such as , require that the quaternion is a unit quaternion.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF.op_Multiply(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF)
member.summary: Multiplies two quaternions.
member.returns: The product of the two quaternions.

remarks.para: If the quaternions are unit quaternions, then each quaternion represents a rotation in 3-dimensional space. The product of two unit quaternions is the concatenation of the two rotations.
q2 q1 is the same as M2 . M1, where M2 and M1 are the equivalent matrices (M1 specifies the same rotation as q1 and M2 specifies the same rotation as q2).
The multiplication is non-commutative. The operation is also known as the Grassman product of quaternions.
The multiplication is defined as:
q1 q2 = (w1 w2 - v1 v2, v1 x v2 + w1 v2 + w2 v1)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF.Multiply(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF)
member.summary: Multiplies two quaternions.
member.returns: The product of the two quaternions.

remarks.para: If the quaternions are unit quaternions, then each quaternion represents a rotation in 3-dimensional space. The product of two unit quaternions is the concatenation of the two rotations.
q1 . q2 is the same as M1 . M2, where M1 and M2 are the equivalent matrices (M1 specifies the same rotation as q1 and M2 specifies the same rotation as q2).
The multiplication is non-commutative. The operation is also known as the Grassman product of quaternions.
The multiplication is defined as:
q1 q2 = (w1 w2 - v1 v2, v1 x v2 + w1 v2 + w2 v1)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF.Exp

overloads.summary: Calculates the exponential.

member.summary: Sets this quaternion to its exponential.

remarks.para: Important: This method requires that the quaternion is a pure quaternion. A pure quaternion is defined by q = (0, u) where u is a unit vector.
The exponential of a quaternion q is defines as:
eq = (cos() + usin())
The result is returned as a quaternion with the form: (cos(), usin())

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF.Ln

overloads.summary: Calculates the natural logarithm.

member.summary: Sets this quaternion to its natural logarithm.

remarks.para: Important: This method requires that the quaternion is a unit quaternion.
The natural logarithm of a quaternion q is defines as:
ln(q) = ln(cos() + usin()) = ln(eu) = u
The result is returned as a quaternion with the form: (0, u)

member.exception: The quaternion is not a unit quaternion.

member.param: If set to then the rotation axes are fixed in world space. Otherwise the rotation axes are fixed on the object and rotated with each rotation.
member.remarks: A rotation is created from 3 sequential rotations. Each rotation is defined by an angle and the rotation axis. This method can be used to create a quaternion from Euler angle representations, often named Azimuth/Elevation/Roll, or Heading/Pitch/Roll.

member.exception: The length of the axis vectors must not be 0.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SorMethodD
member.summary: An iterative solver using the Successive Over Relaxation (SOR) method (double-precision).

remarks.para: See for an introduction to this method and for an explanation of the convergence criterion.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.SorMethodD.RelaxationFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the relaxation factor.
member.value: The relaxation factor. The default value is 1.
member.remarks: When this value is between 0 and 1 the method is termed under-relaxation, and when this value is greater than 1 the method is termed over relaxation. If this value is 1, the SOR method is simply the Gauss-Seidel method.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3D.Forward
member.summary: Returns a unit pointing forward (0, 0, 1). (Only available in the XNA-compatible build.)

remarks.para: This property is available only in the XNA-compatible build of the DigitalRune.Mathematics.dll.

DigitalRune uses the same coordinate systems as the XNA Framework: model space (object space, local space), world space and view space are right-handed coordinate systems where, by default, the positive x-axis points to the right, the positive y-axis points up, and the positive z-axis points towards the viewer.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector3F.Forward
member.summary: Returns a unit pointing forward (0, 0, 1). (Only available in the XNA-compatible build.)

remarks.para: This property is available only in the XNA-compatible build of the DigitalRune.Mathematics.dll.

DigitalRune uses the same coordinate systems as the XNA Framework: model space (object space, local space), world space and view space are right-handed coordinate systems where, by default, the positive x-axis points to the right, the positive y-axis points up, and the positive z-axis points towards the viewer.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.FastFourierTransformD
member.summary: Performs Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) (double-precision).

remarks.para: This class performs a Discrete Fourier transform (DFT) for 1D and 2D samples using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) algorithms. Have a look at DFT and FFT by Paul Bourke for introduction to DFT and FFT. This class uses the same notation. (Please note that the 1 / N factor and the sign of the exponent are switched between forward and inverse FFT in some notations.)
1D FFT can be performed using . This method is static and you do not need to create an instance of this class.
2D FFT can be performed using . This method is not static because it requires an internal buffer, which is allocated only once for each instance. The size of the buffer is determine by .

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.FastFourierTransformD.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximal capacity to reserve for internal buffers.
member.value: The maximal capacity to reserve for internal buffers.
member.remarks: For 2D FFT, the capacity must be the size of largest dimension of the 2D array. For example: To transform an array with 256x512 values, use a capacity of 512.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.FastFourierTransformD.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The max. capacity to reserve for internal buffers. For 2D FFT, this must be the size of largest dimension of the 2D array. For example: To transform an array with 256x512 values, use a capacity of 512.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.FastFourierTransformD.Transform1D(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector2D[],System.Boolean)

overloads.summary: Performs a Fast Fourier Transform in 1 dimension.

member.summary: Performs a Fast Fourier Transform in 1 dimension using the Radix-2 Cooley-Tukey algorithm.
member.param: The values which are replaced in-place by the FFT result. Each element represents a complex number with the real part in x and the imaginary part in y. The number of values must be a power of two (e.g. 2, 4, 8, 16, ...).
to perform forward FFT, to perform inverse FFT.
member.exception: The length of is not a power of two.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.FastFourierTransformD.Transform1D(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.Vector2D[],System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Performs a Fast Fourier Transform using the Radix-2 Cooley-Tukey algorithm.
member.param: The values which are replaced in-place by the FFT result. Each element represents a complex number with the real part in x and the imaginary part in y. The number of values must be a power of two (e.g. 2, 4, 8, 16, ...).
The number of values. The array can be longer. Only the elements from 0 to - 1 are transformed.
to perform forward FFT, to perform inverse FFT.
member.exception: is not a power of two.

member.summary: Performs a Fast Fourier Transform in 2 dimensions.
member.param: The values which are replaced in-place by the FFT result. Each element represents a complex number with the real part in x and the imaginary part in y. The number of values in each dimension must be a power of two (e.g. 2, 4, 8, 16, ...).
to perform forward FFT, to perform inverse FFT.
member.exception: The width or height of the array exceeds the internal buffer or is not a power of two.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.ImprovedNewtonRaphsonMethodD
member.summary: Finds roots using an improved Newton-Raphson method (double-precision).

remarks.para: This root finding algorithm uses a combination of the bisection method and the Newton-Raphson to provide global convergence.
This algorithm needs a function f'(x) which can compute the derivative of the function f(x) as additional inputs.

member.param: The function f(x), which root we want to find.
The function f'(x), which computes the derivative.

member.summary: Finds the root of the given function.
member.param: An x value such that the root lies between and .
An x value such that the root lies between and .
member.returns: The x value such that f(x) = 0; or NaN if no root is found.

member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum number number of iterations.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.OdeIntegratorD
member.summary: A base class for numerical integration strategies for ordinary differential equations (ODE). (Double-precision)

remarks.para: Numerical integration is explained using following example:

Consider the following ODE: dx/dt = f(x, t). The goal of the numerical integration is to compute the state x1 at time t1 when following information is given:
The state at time t0. In general, this state is an n-dimensional vector.
The function f(x, t) that computes the first order derivative of x.
Note: In this documentation we assume that the integration variable is time since this is very common for simulation tasks. Of course the integration variable can be any other quantity.

The function f that computes the first order derivative depends on the state x and the time t: For example, the state in rigid body simulation consist of the positions and velocities of the rigid bodies. When computing the new state of the simulation, the first order derivatives (velocities and accelerations) depend on the whole state and on time. This is because accelerations are computed through forces which depend on time (for example explosions), depend on velocities (damping forces) or depend on positions (spring forces).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.OdeIntegratorD.FirstOrderDerivative
member.summary: Gets the function f(x, t) that computes the first order derivative.
member.value: The function f(x, t) that computes the first order derivative.
member.remarks: The function has the form VectorD Function(VectorD x, double time), where x is the state vector for the given time. The function returns the first order derivative of state x for the given time.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.OdeIntegratorD.#ctor(System.Func{DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.VectorD,System.Double,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.VectorD})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The function f(x, t) that computes the first order derivative of the vector x (see ).

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Analysis.OdeIntegratorD.Integrate(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.VectorD,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the new state x1 at time t1.
member.param: The state x0 at time t0.
The target time t1 for which the new state x1 is computed.
member.returns: The new state x1 at time t1.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ArcSegment2F
member.summary: Defines a 2-dimensional elliptic arc segment (single-precision).

remarks.para: The draws an elliptic arc between the start point and the end point .
To draw a full ellipse, set equal to and to . An ellipse will be drawn so that and lie on the positive x-axis of the ellipse.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ArcSegment2F.Point1
member.summary: Gets or sets the start point.
member.value: The start point. The default value is (1, 0).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ArcSegment2F.Point2
member.summary: Gets or sets the end point.
member.value: The end point. The default value is (0, 1).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ArcSegment2F.IsLargeArc
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the arc should be greater than 180 degrees.
member.value: if the arc should be greater than 180 degrees; otherwise, . The default value is .

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ArcSegment2F.Radius
member.summary: Gets or sets the radii (semi-major and semi-minor axis) of the ellipse.
member.value: The radii of the ellipse. The default value is (1, 1).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ArcSegment2F.RotationAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle from the current x-axis to the x-axis of the ellipse.
member.value: The angle (in radians) from the current x-axis to the x-axis of the ellipse. The default value is 0.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ArcSegment2F.SweepClockwise
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the arc is drawn in clockwise or counter-clockwise direction.
member.value: if the arc is drawn in clockwise direction; otherwise, . The default value is .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.BSplineSegment1F
member.summary: Defines a single segment of a 1-dimensional cubic B-spline (single-precision).

remarks.para: A can be used to smoothly interpolate between two points.

Given a series of points (, , , ) this method performs a smooth approximation between the points and . The approximation curve is known as B-spline. It is not guaranteed that the curve runs through the given points and !

The curve function point = C(parameter) takes a scalar parameter and returns a point on the curve (see ). The curve parameter lies in the interval [0,1]; it is also known as interpolation parameter, interpolation factor or weight of the target point.

member.summary: Gets or sets the previous point.

member.summary: Gets or sets the start point.

member.summary: Gets or sets the end point.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.BSplineSegment1F.Point4
member.summary: Gets or sets the subsequent point.

member.summary: Computes a point on the curve.
member.returns: The curve point.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.BezierSegment1F
member.summary: Defines a single segment of a 1-dimensional cubic Bzier spline (single-precision).

remarks.para: A can be used to smoothly interpolate between two points.
It is a curve that connects two points: and . Two more points are required to define the curvature of the spline: and . The curve smoothly interpolates between and .

The curve is a function point = C(parameter) that takes a scalar parameter and returns a point on the curve (see ). The curve parameter lies in the interval [0,1]; it is also known as interpolation parameter, interpolation factor or weight of the target point. C(0) returns the start point ; C(1) returns the end point .
The curve is defined as:
where u is the curve parameter, p are the start/end points and cp are the control points.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CardinalSegment1F
member.summary: Defines a single segment of a 1-dimensional cubic Cardinal spline (single-precision).

remarks.para: A can be used to smoothly interpolate between two points.

Given a series of points (, , , ) this method performs a smooth interpolation between the points and . The interpolation curve is known as as Cardinal spline. The curve (spline) is a specialization of the cubic Hermit spline. The curve runs through the control points and . The tangent at each point is computed from the previous point and the following point. The tangent ti for point pi is computed as:
ti = 1/2 (1 - tension) (pi+1 - pi-1),
where tension is a parameter, which is a constant that modifies the length of the tangent. tension = 1 will yield zero tangents and tension = 0 yields a Catmull-Rom spline.

The curve function point = C(parameter) takes a scalar parameter and returns a point on the curve (see ). The curve parameter lies in the interval [0,1]; it is also known as interpolation parameter, interpolation factor or weight of the target point. C(0) returns the start point ; C(1) returns the end point .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Curve2F
member.summary: Represents a 2-dimensional curve that is used to define a function y = f(x) (single-precision).

remarks.para: In contrast to general curves, the is a specialized type of curve that is used to define a function y = f(x).

A general curve is function of the form p = C(u). The curve parameter u is a scalar. The result of C(u) is a point p on the curve. In the 2-dimensional case (see ) the function can be written as (x, y) = C(u).
The is a special type of curve where the curve parameter and the x-component of the resulting points are identical: (x, y) = C(x).

Application: A can be used to define an animation curve. An animation curve describes how a quantity y (size, offset, etc.) evolves over time. the curve parameter is typically time. These curves must be monotonic in the parameter axis (x-axis). There can only be one valid y value for each curve parameter x.

Curve Keys: The curve keys () define the control points of the curve. The parameter of the curve keys (see ) are always identical to the x-component of the points (see ). Therefore, it is not necessary to set the curve parameter manually.

The curve keys are interpolated using spline interpolation. Each curve key defines the type of spline interpolation that is used from this curve key to the next (see ). Some types of interpolation require additional information: requires additional control points and requires tangents. These values are stored in the properties and of the curve keys.
It is possible to specify invalid control points or tangents. Neither nor checks whether the values in or are a valid. In general, the results are undefined if a curve contains invalid tangents.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Curve2F.GetCycleOffset(System.Single)
member.summary: Gets the cycle offset for a given parameter.
member.returns: The cycle offset.
member.remarks: The cycle offset is 0 if the is unequal to or if the is on the curve.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Curve2F.GetTangent(System.Single)
member.summary: Computes the tangent for a point on the curve.
member.returns: The curve tangent. If the function is not differentiable at the given parameter, either the incoming or outgoing tangent is returned.

remarks.para:
The curve tangent can be used to compute the slope k of the function at the given parameter.
Vector2F tangent = curve.GetTangent(0.5f); // Get the tangent at x = 0.5. float k = tangent.Y / tangent.X; // Compute the slope at x = 0.5.
If the curve keys contain invalid tangents, the results are undefined.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Curve2F.GetLength(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Not supported.
member.param: The parameter value of the start position.
The parameter value of the end position.
The maximum number of iterations which are taken to compute the length.
The tolerance value. This method will return an approximation of the precise length. The absolute error will be less than this tolerance.
member.returns: The approximated length of the curve in the given interval.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveKey`2
member.summary: Defines a curve key (control point) of a piecewise curve.
member.typeparam: The type of the curve parameter (usually or ).
The type of the curve points (such as , , etc.).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveKey`2.Parameter
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that defines where this curve key is positioned on the curve.
member.value: The parameter value.

remarks.para: The parameter is normally zero at the first curve key and increases as we move along the curve.

Depending on where or how the curve is used the curve parameter could be interpreted as time (to describe when a certain point is reached) or distance (to describe the distance from the start of the curve). Other interpretations can be used as well.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveKey`2.Point
member.summary: Gets or sets the curve point for this curve key.
member.value: The curve point (control point).
member.remarks: Depending on the type of interpolation that is used for the current segment of the curve, the key may be point on the curve (see , , , , , , ) or may only be a control point that does not directly on the curve (see ).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveKey`2.TangentIn
member.summary: Gets or sets the incoming tangent or the control point before this curve key.
member.value: The incoming tangent or the control point before this curve key.

remarks.para: This property is used to compute previous curve segment (the spline that ends at this curve key).

The meaning of this property depends on the type of interpolation that is for the previous curve segment:
SplineInterpolation Meaning
Hermite splines require tangent information. Therefore, this property defines the incoming tangent of the spline that ends at this curve key.
Bzier splines require additional control points. Therefore, this property defines the control point before this curve key.
Other
All other types of interpolation do not need any additional information. The property is unused.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveKey`2.TangentOut
member.summary: Gets or sets the outgoing tangent or the control point after this curve key.
member.value: The outgoing tangent or the control point after this curve key.

remarks.para: This property is used to compute the current curve segment (the spline that starts at this curve key).

The meaning of this property depends on the type of interpolation that is for the current curve segment:
SplineInterpolation Meaning
Hermite splines require tangent information. Therefore, this property defines the outgoing tangent of the spline between this curve key and the next.
Bzier splines require additional control points. Therefore, this property defines the control point after this curve key.
Other
All other types of interpolation do not need any additional information. The property is unused.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveKey`2.Interpolation
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of interpolation (the spline type) used for the current curve segment between this key and the next key.
member.value: The type of interpolation used for the current curve segment (the spline between this curve key and the next curve key).

member.summary: Gets the parameter.
member.returns: The parameter.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveLoopType
member.summary: Defines how a curve is continued before the first curve key or after the last curve key.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveLoopType.Constant
member.summary: The curve value is constant and equal to the nearest key.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveLoopType.Linear
member.summary: The curve value is a linear extrapolation of the nearest key value in the direction of the tangent.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveLoopType.Cycle
member.summary: Parameters specified past the ends of the curve will wrap around to the opposite side of the curve. If the values of the first and last key are different, the value will "jump" instantly from one value to the other at the curve ends.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveLoopType.CycleOffset
member.summary: Same as but the curve values are offset by the difference of the first and last key value. Unlike the curve is continued without "jumps" at the curve ends.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.CurveLoopType.Oscillate
member.summary: Parameters specified past the ends of the curve act as an offset from the same side of the curve toward the opposite side. This is similar to where the curve is mirrored beyond the curve ends.

remarks.para: A can be used to smoothly interpolate between two points.

The curve function point = C(parameter) takes a scalar parameter and returns a point on the curve (see ). member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.HermiteSegment2F
member.summary: Defines a single segment of a 2-dimensional cubic Hermite spline (single-precision).

remarks.para: A can be used to smoothly interpolate between two points.
The curve runs through the points and . The tangents at these points can be controlled with and . The curve smoothly interpolates between and .
Multiple splines can be patched together by matching the tangents at the control points.

The curve function point = C(parameter) takes a scalar parameter and returns a point on the curve (see ). The curve parameter lies in the interval [0,1]; it is also known as interpolation parameter, interpolation factor or weight of the target point. C(0) returns the start point ; C(1) returns the end point .
The curve is defined as:
where u is the interpolation parameter, p are the start/end points and t are the start/end tangents.

member.summary: Represents a curve.
member.typeparam: The type of the curve parameter (usually or ).
The type of the curve points (such as , , etc.).

remarks.para: Curves can be used to describe animation curves, 2D paths, 3D paths, and more.
Mathematically, a curve is a function of the form point = C(parameter). The curve parameter is a scalar. The result of C(parameter) is a point on the curve.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ICurve`2.GetLength(`0,`0,System.Int32,`0)
member.summary: Computes the approximated length of the curve for the parameter interval [, ].
member.param: The parameter value of the start position.
The parameter value of the end position.
The maximum number of iterations which are taken to compute the length.
The tolerance value. This method will return an approximation of the precise length. The absolute error will be less than this tolerance.
member.returns: The approximated length of the curve for the given parameter interval.
member.remarks: For some curves the length is computed with an iterative algorithm. The iterations end when the were performed, or when the criterion is met - whichever comes first.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ICurve`2.Flatten(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{`1},System.Int32,`0)

overloads.summary: Computes the points of a sequence of line segments which approximate the curve.

member.summary: Computes the points of a sequence of line segments which approximate the curve.
member.param: A collection to which all points of the line segments are added. See remarks.
The maximum number of iterations which are taken to compute the approximation.
The tolerance value. The absolute error of the approximated polygon will be less than this tolerance.

remarks.para: This method computes a sequence of line segments which approximates the curve. For each line segment, the start and end point are added to . For example, if a curve is approximated with two line segments (A, B) and (B, C) where A, B, C are three key points, then following points will be added to collection: A, B, B, C. This means, that duplicate points are added to the collection. The advantage of this is that the approximation can represent "gaps" in the curve. And it is easy to flatten several curves into the same collection.
For some curves the approximation is computed with an iterative algorithm. The iterations end when the were performed, or when the criterion is met - whichever comes first.

member.summary: Performs a linear interpolation between two values (single-precision).
member.param: The interpolation parameter that lies in the interval [0,1]; also known as interpolation factor or weight of the target value.
member.returns: The linear interpolation of two values.

remarks.para: Lerp(a, b, 0) returns a. Lerp(a, b, 1) returns b.

overloads.summary: Computes the function value for using polynomial interpolation.

member.summary: Computes the function value for using polynomial interpolation (single-precision).
member.returns: The interpolated value y = P(x).
member.remarks: Through any N points there is a unique polynomial P(x) of order N-1. This method constructs the interpolating polynomial through the given points using Neville's algorithm. And computes the function value for the given function argument x.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.InterpolationHelper.Slerp(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,System.Single)

overloads.summary: Performs a spherical linear interpolation of the two quaternions.

member.summary: Performs a spherical linear interpolation of the two .
member.param: The interpolation factor that lies in the interval [0,1]; also known as interpolation factor or weight of the target value.
member.returns: The spherical linear interpolation of the two quaternions.

remarks.para: Important: The method assumes the quaternions and are unit quaternions (i.e. they are normalized).
Rotations specified by unit quaternions can be interpolated with an operation known as spherical linear interpolation (SLERP). The operation is defined as:

slerp(q0, q1, t) = (q0 sin((1-t)) + q1 sin(t)) / sin where
q0, q1 are unit quaternions representing start and destination rotation,
t is the interpolation factor which lies in the interval [0, 1], and
is the angle between q0 and q1, which can be determined by the dot product of q0 and q1.
The interpolation can lie outside of the interval [0, 1]. Outside of this interval the method actually performs an extrapolation instead of an interpolation.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.InterpolationHelper.Slerp(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,System.Double)
member.summary: Performs a spherical linear interpolation of the two .
member.param: The interpolation factor that lies in the interval [0,1]; also known as interpolation factor or weight of the target value.
member.returns: The spherical linear interpolation of the two quaternions.

remarks.para: Important: The method assumes the quaternions and are unit quaternions (i.e. they are normalized).
Rotations specified by unit quaternions can be interpolated with an operation known as spherical linear interpolation (SLERP). The operation is defined as:

slerp(q0, q1, t) = (q0 sin((1-t)) + q1 sin(t)) / sin where
q0, q1 are unit quaternions representing start and destination rotation,
t is the interpolation factor which lies in the interval [0, 1], and
is the angle between q0 and q1, which can be determined by the dot product of q0 and q1.
The interpolation can lie outside of the interval [0, 1]. Outside of this interval the method actually performs an extrapolation instead of an interpolation.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.InterpolationHelper.Squad(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionF,System.Single)

overloads.summary: Interpolates between quaternions using spherical quadrangle interpolation.

member.summary: Interpolates between quaternions using spherical quadrangle interpolation (single-precision).
member.returns: The interpolated quaternion.

remarks.para: The spherical quadrangle interpolation (SQUAD) is a spline-based interpolation of rotations (unit quaternion). This operation is also known as spherical cubic interpolation.
If qn is a sequence of N quaternions (n = 0 to N-1), then the smooth interpolation is given by:

squad(qn, an, an+1, qn+1, t) = slerp(slerp(qn, qn+1, t), slerp(an, an+1, t), 2t(1-t)) where
qn, qn+1 represent start and destination rotation,
t is the interpolation parameter which lies in the interval [0, 1], and
an, an+1 are intermediate quaternions which can be determined with:
an = qn e-(ln(qn-1qn-1) + ln(qn-1qn+1))/4

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.InterpolationHelper.Squad(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.QuaternionD,System.Double)
member.summary: Interpolates between quaternions using spherical quadrangle interpolation (double-precision).
member.returns: The interpolated quaternion.

remarks.para: The spherical quadrangle interpolation (SQUAD) is a spline-based interpolation of rotations (unit quaternion). This operation is also known as spherical cubic interpolation.
If qn is a sequence of N quaternions (n = 0 to N-1), then the smooth interpolation is given by:

squad(qn, an, an+1, qn+1, t) = slerp(slerp(qn, qn+1, t), slerp(an, an+1, t), 2t(1-t)) where
qn, qn+1 represent start and destination rotation,
t is the interpolation parameter which lies in the interval [0, 1], and
an, an+1 are intermediate quaternions which can be determined with:
an = qn e-(ln(qn-1qn-1) + ln(qn-1qn+1))/4

overloads.summary: Calculates the parameters for a spline-based quaternion interpolation.

member.summary: Calculates the parameters for a spline-based quaternion interpolation (single-precision).

overloads.summary: Updates position and velocity according to a critically damped spring.

member.summary: Updates position and velocity according to a critically damped spring (single-precision).
member.param: is parameter that determines how fast the is reached. is equal to the time that is required to reach the target when at maximum speed.

remarks.para: At the beginning of the method and are the current position and velocity of an object. The object should move to the . At the end of the method and are updated to the new position after has elapsed.
The position and velocity are changed according to the movement of a critically damped spring. This generates a smooth movement that can be used to interpolate values.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.InterpolationHelper.HermiteSmoothStep(System.Single)

overloads.summary: Computes the Hermite smooth step function.

member.summary: Computes the Hermite smooth step function (single-precision).
member.returns: The function value y.

remarks.para: This functions can be visualized as an S-shaped curve based on a Hermite base function: y = x2 ( 3 - 2x ). (This polynomial is one of the base functions of the cubic Hermite spline.)
The function value y goes from 0 to 1 as x goes from 0 to 1. y = 0 for x < 0 and y = 1 for x > 1.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.InterpolationHelper.EaseInOutSmoothStep(System.Single)

overloads.summary: Computes a constant acceleration ease-in/ease-out smooth step function.

member.summary: Computes a constant acceleration ease-in/ease-out smooth step function (single-precision).
member.returns: The function value y.

remarks.para: This functions can be visualized as an S-shaped curve based on a constant-acceleration ease-in/ease-out behavior.
The function value y goes from 0 to 1 as x goes from 0 to 1. y = 0 for x < 0 and y = 1 for x > 1.

To understand how the function works, let's assume that x is time and y is the distance. The function starts at x = 0 with 0 velocity and constant acceleration. The velocity increases until x = 0.5. Then the velocity decreases with constant acceleration and at x = 1 the velocity is 0.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.LineSegment1F
member.summary: Defines a 1-dimensional line segment (single-precision).

remarks.para: A performs linear interpolation (LERP) between two values.

The curve function point = C(parameter) takes a scalar parameter and returns a point on the curve (see ). The curve parameter lies in the interval [0,1]; it is also known as interpolation parameter, interpolation factor or weight of the target point. C(0) returns the start point ; C(1) returns the end point .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Path2F
member.summary: Represents a 2-dimensional path that is defined by piecewise interpolation of key points (single-precision).

remarks.para: A is a "piecewise curve". That means, the path is defined by key points () that are interpolated using spline interpolation. See for more information on piecewise curves.

Path Keys: The path keys () define the control points of the path. Each path key defines a point on the curve . These points are interpolated using spline interpolation. Each path key defines the type of spline interpolation that is used from this path key to the next (see ). The path keys also contain additional information that might me required for interpolation such as: , .

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Path2F.GetCycleOffset(System.Single)
member.summary: Gets the cycle offset for a given parameter.
member.returns: The cycle offset.
member.remarks: The cycle offset is a zero vector if the is unequal to or if the is on the curve.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Path2F.ParameterizeByLength(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Parameterizes the path by its length.
member.param: The maximum number of iterations which are taken to compute the length.
The tolerance value. This method will return an approximation of the precise length. The absolute error will be less than this tolerance.
member.remarks: Normally, the is not equal to the length of the curve from the first key up to the current key. This method will compute length of the segments and set the key s to the distance from the first key. The parameter of the first key will be set to 0. The parameter of the second key will be set to the length of the first segment. The parameter of the third key will be set to the added length of the first two segments. And so on.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Path2F.GetSpline(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the spline after the key with the given index.
member.returns: The spline or if the interpolation is none of the implemented spline classes.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.Path2F.GetParameterFromLength(System.Single,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Gets the curve parameter for the given curve length (for length-parameterized splines).
member.param: The maximum number of iterations which are taken to compute the length.
The tolerance value. This method will return an approximation of the precise parameter. The absolute error will be less than this tolerance.
member.returns: The parameter at which the curve has the given length.

remarks.para: This method assumes that the spline is length-parameterized; This means: The parameter of a key is equal to the length of the spline at this key. If this is not the case, can be called to correct the key parameters automatically.

Normally, the spline curve parameter is not linearly proportional to the length. Therefore, if the point at a given curve length is required, this method can be used to compute the curve parameter which will return the point for the given distance. The result of this method can be used in .
This method uses an iterative algorithm. The iterations end when the were performed, or when the criterion is met - whichever comes first.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3
member.summary: Represents a curve that is defined by piecewise interpolation of curve keys (control points).
member.typeparam: The type of the curve parameter (usually or ).
The type of the curve points (such as , , etc.).
The type of the curve key. (A type derived from .)

remarks.para: A "piecewise curve", also known as "spline", is a curve with arbitrary length that is defined by concatenating multiple curve segments.
The is a collection of curve keys (). Each curve key is a control point that defines a point on the curve. The points between curve keys are created by spline interpolation of the curve keys.
The curve keys are also called "key frames" if the path represents an animation curve, or "waypoints" if the path represents a 2-dimensional or 3-dimensional path.
Curve keys in a must not be .
The methods in this interface assume that the curve keys are sorted ascending by the curve parameter (see ). If this is not the case, you can call to sort keys.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3.PostLoop
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that defines how the curve looks after the last curve key.
member.value: The post-loop behavior. The default value is .
member.remarks: The parameter of the last curve key defines the end of the curve. If the user specifies a parameter in a curve method that is greater, this property defines which curve keys and values are used for computations.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3.PreLoop
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that defines how the curve looks before the first path key.
member.value: The pre-loop behavior. The default value is .
member.remarks: The parameter of the first curve key defines the start of the curve. If the user specifies a parameter in a curve method that is less, this property defines which curve keys and values are used for computations.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3.SmoothEnds
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the curve ends are smoothed.
member.value: if the curve ends are smoothed; otherwise, . The default value is
member.remarks: This property is only relevant if the path ends are B-splines or Catmull Rom splines. Theses spline types need additional neighbor points. At the path ends these neighbor points are missing. Per default, neighbor points are generated internally by mirroring the neighbor point on the other side of an end point through the end point. If this flag is set to , other virtual neighbor points are generated which result in a smoother curve.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3.GetKeyIndex(`0)
member.summary: Gets the index of the curve key before or at the given parameter value.
member.returns: The index of the curve key or -1 if no suitable curve key exists.
member.remarks: This method assumes that the curve keys are sorted and returns index of the key with the largest value that is less than or equal to the given parameter value. The parameter will lie between the key at the returned index and the key at index + 1. If is beyond the start or end of the path, a key index according to and is returned.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3.InsertItem(System.Int32,`2)
member.summary: Inserts an element into the at the specified index.
member.param: The zero-based index at which should be inserted.
The object to insert. The value can be null for reference types.
member.exception: is less than zero. Or is greater than .

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3.IsInMirroredOscillation(`0)
member.summary: Determines whether the given parameter corresponds to a mirrored oscillation loop.
member.returns: if the parameter is in a mirrored oscillation loop; otherwise, .
member.remarks: When the parameter is less than the parameter of the first key or greater than the parameter of the last key, then the parameter is outside the regular curve. The outside behavior is determined by and . If the loop type is the curve is mirrored after each loop cycle. This method returns if the parameter is outside and belongs to a curve loop which is mirrored to the regular curve.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.PiecewiseCurve`3.LoopParameter(`0)
member.summary: Handles pre- and post-looping by changing the given parameter so that it lies on the curve.
member.returns: The modified parameter value.

remarks.para: If the parameter lies outside the curve the parameter is changed so that it lies on the curve. The new parameter can be used to compute the curve result.

Following s need special handling:
: The parameter is not changed to lie on the curve; the linear extrapolation of the curve has to be computed.
: The parameter is corrected to be on the curve; the curve function at this parameter can be evaluated and the offset must be added. The curve point offset is not handled in this method.
