member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.RadialBasisRegressionF
member.summary: Scattered Interpolation using multiple regression analysis with radial basis functions (single-precision).

remarks.para: Radial basis functions are described in the paper "Pose Space Deformation: A Unified Approach to Shape Interpolation and Skeleton-Driven Deformation".
The regression can numerically fail for bad reference data pairs or an inappropriate basis function. In this case will throw a .

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.RadialBasisRegressionF.BasisFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the basis function.

value.para: The basis function. The first parameter is the distance of the new data point x to the reference data point xi, which has been computed by the distance function. The second parameter is the index i of the reference data point xi. (The second parameter is ignored by default. The same basis function is applied for all reference data points. However, the index could be used to select a unique basis function for each reference data point.)

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.RadialBasisRegressionF.DistanceFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance function.

value.para: The distance function that computes the distance between a new data point x and the reference data point xi. The first parameter is the new data point x. The second parameter is the reference data point xi. The third parameter is the index i of the reference data point xi. (The third parameter can be ignored in most cases.)
The default distance function computes the Euclidean distance between x and xi.
(The distance function could be generalized to the Mahalanobis distance.)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.RadialBasisRegressionF.OnSetup
member.summary: Called when is called.
member.remarks: Here internal values can be computed from the registered reference pairs if required. It is assured that the reference data pairs have valid dimensions: All x values have the same number of elements and all y values have the same number of elements. All reference data values are not .
member.exception: Cannot compute regression - try to choose different reference data pairs or another basis function.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.RadialBasisRegressionF.OnCompute(DigitalRune.Mathematics.Algebra.VectorF)
member.summary: Called when is called.
member.returns: The y value.
member.remarks: When this method is called, has already been executed. And the parameter is not .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.ScatteredInterpolationF
member.summary: Base class for scattered interpolation methods (single-precision).

remarks.para: Scattered interpolation solves the following problem: Several data pairs have been observed: (x1, y1), (x2, y2), (x3, y3), ... These are the reference data values. Now a new x is measured and the y value for the given x is wanted.

The x values are m-dimensional vectors. The y values are n-dimensional vectors. All x vectors must have equal dimensions and all y vectors must have equal dimensions. But the dimension of the x vectors are usually different than the dimension of the y vectors.

item.description:
First the reference data pairs have to be created using the class and registered by calling . The first item of each data pair is the x vector, the second item is the y vector. For example:
scatteredInterpolation.Add(new Pair<VectorF, VectorF>(x, y));
After all reference data pairs are added, has to be called.
Then can be called to compute y values for any given x values. If the reference data pairs are changed, it is necessary to call before the next call of .

remarks.para: Notes to Inheritors: Derived types need to implement the methods and .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Interpolation.StepSegment1F
member.summary: Defines a step interpolation between two values (single-precision).

remarks.para: The curve function point = C(parameter) takes a scalar parameter and returns a point on the curve (see ). The curve parameter lies in the interval [0,1]; it is also known as interpolation parameter, interpolation factor or weight of the target point. C(0) returns the start point ; C(1) returns the end point . The curve is not continuous; it consist only of the two points, and .
The tangents and the length of this special kind of curve are zero.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.FastGaussianDistributionD
member.summary: Creates random values using an approximate Gaussian distribution (double-precision).

remarks.para: Gaussian distribution is also known as Normal distribution.

The random values generated by this class follow only an approximate Gaussian distribution. The distribution curve can be imagined as a typical Gaussian bell curve within +/- 3 standard deviations. All random values lie in the interval [ - 3 * , + 3 * ]. No random values outside the +/- 3 standard deviation interval are returned.

This approximation is faster and makes the random values more controllable for game applications. For example, if in a game tree heights are determined using a real Gaussian distribution with an expected value of 10m and a standard deviation of 1m, then most trees will have a height near 10m. But it would also be possible - unlikely but possible - that a tree with height 30m is generated. This would look very odd. Therefore, it is desirable that the created random values do not exceed 3 standard deviations.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.FastGaussianDistributionD.ExpectedValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the expected value.
member.value: The expected value. The default is 0.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.FastGaussianDistributionD.StandardDeviation
member.summary: Gets or sets the standard deviation.
member.value: The standard deviation. The default is 1.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.NamespaceDoc

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PerlinNoise
member.summary: Computes Improved Perlin Noise.

remarks.para: This class implements "improved noise" by Ken Perlin for 1D, 2D, 3D and 4D.

General noise is simply a collection of random values, like the random dot pattern on old TVs when there is no input signal. General noise is not smooth. Band-limited noise is a noise which is smooth. This can be generated by zooming into the noise pattern and applying a Gaussian blur. A more efficient version of band-limited noise is Perlin Noise.
Perlin Noise is a Gradient Noise: It use a grid of gradients. The noise is 0 at the grid points, i.e. for 3D Compute((int)x, (int)y, (int)z) == 0.
Between grid points the gradients are interpolated to created smooth noise. There is at most one oscillation between two grid points.
Perlin noise is consistent: For a constant position this method always returns the same noise value.

The resulting noise is scaled to keep values the range [-1, 1]. (This is only approximated using scaling factors determined by experimentation. Some returned noise values might still be outside [-1, 1].)

This class can also compute periodic/tileable noise for any integer period, such that:
Compute(x, y, z, periodX, periodY, periodZ) == Compute(x + periodX, y + periodY, z + periodZ, periodX, periodY, periodZ)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PerlinNoise.Noise(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)

overloads.summary: Computes a noise value. Obsolete

member.summary: Computes a 3d noise value for a 3d position given by (x, y, z).
member.returns: The 3d noise value for the given position (x, y, z).

para.i: This method is obsolete. Use instead.

remarks.para: Perlin noise is consistent: For a constant position this method always returns the same noise value.
The noise should be in the range [-1, 1]. The noise value at integer positions is 0, for example Noise(11, 12, 13) = 0.
There is at max one oscillation (1 whole sine period) between two consecutive integer value.
Random values are generated per table lookup. Since the table is limited, the noise function repeats itself after 256 values: Noise(i, 0, 0) == Noise(i + 256, 0, 0)

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PerlinNoise.Noise(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes a 3d noise value for a 3d position given by (x, y, z).
member.returns: The 3d noise value for the given position (x, y, z).

remarks.para: This method is obsolete. It is recommended to manually combine noise generated by the PerlinNoise.Compute methods as required. For example: .

A noise value is computed as in except that several noise functions with different frequencies (octaves) are added, for example for 3 octaves: noiseValue = Noise(x,y,z) + 1/2*Noise(2x, 2y, 2z) + 1/4*Noise(4x,4y,4z)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PrincipalComponentAnalysisD
member.summary: Performs a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) using the covariance method (double-precision).

remarks.para: This class takes a list of data points, computes the covariance matrix C and performs on the covariance matrix. The resulting eigenvectors represent the uncorrelated principal components of the data. The principal components ("natural axes") are the basis of a new coordinate system where the covariance matrix is a diagonal matrix. The first principal component is the direction where the variance of the data projected onto the principal component is greatest. The second greatest variance is on the second principal component, and so forth.

The matrix of the principal components () is an orthogonal matrix, with C = V * D * VT, where C is the covariance matrix and D is the diagonal covariance matrix in the space formed by the principal components.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PrincipalComponentAnalysisD.V
member.summary: Gets the matrix of the principal components.
member.value: The matrix of the principal components.
member.remarks: Each column in this matrix represents a principal component. Columns are ordered by decreasing variance.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Mathematics.Statistics.PrincipalComponentAnalysisD.Variances
member.summary: Gets the variances.
member.value: The variances.
member.remarks: Each element in the vector represents the variance of the data points along a principle component. The variances are sorted by decreasing value, so that the largest variance is the first element.

member.param: The list of data points. All points must have the same .

member.remarks: The and the define a spherical shell. Random values that are created are from the volume of this shell. If is 0 (default), random values from the whole sphere volume are created. If is equal to , all random positions lie on the surface of the sphere.
